Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2016 08:09PM Jelson wrote: framer- what you are going through right now is, most will agree, the worst. NOT KNOWING is the worst. For me too - it is the ribs that hurt the worst after a mammo. I am 65 and have been "with" but not married the whole time to my husband since 1968! Mine doesn't get agitated and worried about unknown stuff, so I guess I can be grateful for that.. If you have cleaned everything, how about cooking something interesting?
Posts.Title: very stupid question from 66 year old female framer

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2013 08:19PM Jelson wrote: I am assuming, like me, you are post menopause? although I am still on tamoxifen - will be done Aug 2014 - I am scheduled for a hysteroscopy and d&c due to spotting and based on a transvaginal ultrasound - thickening of the uterine lining and a polyp. The diagnostic radiologist told me that the tamoxifen can cause thickening of the uterine lining and spotting but that a few months after stopping tamoxifen - the lining should shrink - quite a bit if post- menopausal. I would think that for you, four years after stopping tamoxifen - tamoxifen is not causing your spotting - but, even if it were the tamoxifen - you need to get this checked out. There are many possible reasons (non-cancer) reasons for spotting - you just need to get it checked. Good luck
Posts.Title: Anyone who is post tamoxifen -4 yrs heartbroken08 pupmom

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2010 08:16PM Jelson wrote: If your diagnosis is DCIS- Ductal Cancer In SITU, your stage will be 0, You will find out from the pathology report what grade (1-3) with 3 indicating the cells are more abnormal, you will get an estimate of the area of DCIS, and perhaps what type of DCIS, and how large are the margins of DCIS-free tissue surrounding the lump which was removed.  you will also find out whether the DCIS is ER and/or PR receptive (+). You wil meet with the surgeon and get recommendations on a treatment plan which include combinations of watchful waiting, additional surgery to achieve larger margins, radiation, tamoxifen and/or mastectomy. It is strongly advised that you get a second opinion of your pathology slides and of your treatment plan. Certainly, come visit us on the DCIS board now or when/if you are diagnosed. There are many women who will help you - from those who are years from diagnosis/treatment to those just a few steps ahead of you. A poster named BEESIE has many easy to understand and informatiive posts. There are Young women who probably share many of your age- specific issues and concerns. In addition to the information in the reference section of BCO, there are other websites with info on DCIS. here is one I like:- www.dcis.info/dcis.html Hopefully all will be found benign,in any event, the very best of luck to you on your excisional biopsy tomorrow.  Julie E
Posts.Title: i need HELP!!!! jodi4lsu TheBrightSide

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2015 11:54AM Jelson wrote: pardon me if the resources you mention in your initial post already cover this, but if not, here is an article that explains the relationship between dragon boating and post-breast cancer treatment exercise. http://ldihealtheconomist.com/he000025.shtml I had the pleasure to participate in the 2010 International Dragon Boat Festival for Breast Cancer Survivors held in Peterborough, ON, Canada and I believe there are have been 2 international festivals since then. Dragon Boat paddling is recognized around the world as an excellent upper body(it is actually a whole body )exercise for breast cancer survivors.

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2015 02:16PM Jelson wrote: brilliant to wear a fitbit while kayaking - will have to try that. Kudos to you to kayak with lymphedema. it is heartening to know that if I do get it, I will still be able to kayak. I go out several times a week between March and November, paddling an average of 12 miles in a 5-6 hour outing. Mostly on the Hudson River - taking advantage of the tide! I help spot bald eagles for my husband who takes photographs of birds, plants, tugs/barges, beavers etc from his kayak. The baby eagles are practicing flying now, so alot of my time recently has been spent bobbing around!! I tried googling kayaking breast cancer in different ways to see if there have been studies on the impact of kayaking on lymphedema or breast cancer survivor wellness, but I haven't come up with anything yet. I wonder whether dragon boating, in which you paddle a single bladed paddle, using both left and right arms/shoulders but differently - has been considered more amenable to breast cancer survivors because it gives a left or right side option. allowing the paddler to sit on the side which provides the most comfort and least strain to the side which with they might be having trouble/pain..

Posts.Content: May 13, 2011 01:59PM Jelson wrote: Here is a url for info on the Gail Model. http://www.cancer.gov/bcrisktool/breast-cancer-risk.aspx I am due for my 3rd MRI in a few weeks. For a breast MRI, you are on your stomach - tell the technicians if you need more/less padding in a particular place - their goal is to have you stay still. - I don't get a claustrophobic feeling - maybe because the room is bright and I am on my stomach - a position I don't associate with being buried alive - an idea I hope I am not introducing to you, I mention because it is often the complaint about MRIs.  I focus on the weird sounds and I try to count the seconds, like however many make up 20 minutes. Last year the procedure was done before my counting was done - so much for 1 mississippi, 2 mississippi........ You don't sound pathetic at all, many people share your fears. I didn't know about the iv before my first MRI, maybe I would have freaked too if I had the time to think about it!  Hold this thought: You are very lucky to be given the opportunity to have an MRI which will hopefully identify what you have been watching for more than a year.   Julie E

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2010 04:38PM Jelson wrote: Elizabeth I am a book-loving lurker Konokat fan, so this is the first time I am posting on this Board. I wanted to recommend The Sweetness at the Bottom of the Pie by Alan Bradley (a Canadian writer!!!). The smart and funny eleven-year old protagonist, Flavia De Luce reminds me of you. The setting is an estate in rural England-1950 - not where I would have thought I would have wanted to spend time - but it was the type of book, that I didn't want to end.  Another recent one is The War Against Miss Winter - a down on her luck actress in NYC - 1943 who takes a part time job at a detective agency - she is feisty, mouthy and a lot of fun.....also like you. wishing the best to you, Julie E

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2010 05:34AM Jelson wrote: I guess I am slow or thick-skinned, I remember driving over a bridge one night before christmas several years ago listening to NPR on which there was someone reading an essay about gifts. One of the funny gifts I chuckled over was bath salts for someone who didn't have a bathtub. I laughed but began to think about the gift I had gotten the year before from my DH, good grief, a dozen bath cubes and we don't have a bathtub either!! I shrieked and almost drove off the bridge. When we were trying to get pregnant he emptied our kitty litter box and began to hate our cats. He ultimately banished them from the house 6 months of the year and was just mean about them. Anyway, they eventually died off (respectable ages). Well, what starts popping up as the theme for my Christmas presents? CATS: Cat socks, Cat this, Cat that. Finally a victoriana type pin which was an open cat's mouth framing a mouse. I said ENOUGH, I love living cats, not cat stuff.

Posts.Content: May 18, 2011 05:26PM Jelson wrote: http://www.shop3m.com/70200763947.html above is info about it. and here is a blog from 2008 by a husband whose wife used it instead of what the doctor recommended. http://coopergordon.blogspot.com/2008/06/experience-with-cavilon.html he explains how it differs from the normal moisturizers recommended by the NHS. He talks about their experience and suggestions for how to apply, he suggests the cream instead - which is also featured on the 3m website above. I was reassured when I read the blog, he has a hot link to a study comparing cavilon to a product normally suggested for bc radiation - in australia. if you google cavilon radiation - the study comes up as well. Don't be put off by the fact that this "cavilon" family of products seem to have orignally been intended for colostomy bag users and to protect skin from incontinence - hey, it sounds like it works and does not interfere with radiation.  This is kind of exciting - something new!! . If you check through the radiation discussion board, you will find that many products have been recommended. I know the radiology practice where I got my radiation recommended dove soap for sensitive skin and pure aloe vera gel - mainly because these worked and were cheap.  This cavilon might work better but be more expensive.  I certainly hope you breeze through your radiation! Julie E

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2015 09:23AM Jelson wrote: Although there were cancers in my family, most of my relatives had died from lung cancer or heart issues, so those were what I was concerned about and a diagnosis of breast cancer was simply not on my radar either. Perhaps the surgeon is concerned that because you are so very optimistic that the findings are going to be benign, that if indeed, a malignancy is found, you will find it especially difficult to absorb and to be able to cope. So even though he was a bit abrupt, he has planted a seed in your mind, that you might indeed have BC. The fact that you are learning more about BC, wrapping your head around the possibility, is probably the reaction he was hoping for. When I was told by my surgeon, post biopsy, that I had DCIS - and she explained how the cells were not capable of breaking through the duct wall. I said, oh, they are too stupid - she responded, this is not a joke. this is serious. I felt a bit huffy, I can tell you!!! and then a friend of mine, when I tried to minimize my diagnosis, said quite harshly to me, this is serious, I have friends who died from BC - well that got me very angry. But both the surgeon's comments, and my friend's comments nudged me to accept that this was my new reality and were the impetus for my seeking and finding BCO. I sincerely hope that your findings are benign and that BC is not your new reality, and that you can laugh in that surgeon's face. But if it is BC, you may not be as blindsided by the diagnosis as you would have been if the surgeon hadn't said what he said.

Posts.Content: May 14, 2010 10:31AM Jelson wrote: skyelee - I am sorry that your internist frightened you, it sounds like she is frightened for you - but remember she is an internist, not a breast cancer specialist. Eventhough you can't take someone with you, can someone be on speaker phone from the surgeon's office or perhaps could you record what the doctor says? and if those alternatives aren't practical for you, ask for a report of your visit with the surgeon, because much, if not all of the pertinent information discussed should be on the report of the visit.AND check with your internist/radiologist to make sure that the surgeon has been sent your mammograms and ultrasounds - you may have to actually pick them up and bring them to the appt yourself. I scrolled around in the Symptoms and Diagnosis section of BCO and found a page with information on exactly where you are - early diagnosis stage www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/...  It will help you make a list of questions to ask, I bet someone else with respond to your posting with an actual list, I just wanted to make sure you didn't feel like you were left hanging by us, even for a few minutes! Good luck, hopefully your results will be benign - keep us posted. Julie E

Posts.Title: Just when I think I'm good to go.... Suesinstitches Suesinstitches

Posts.Content: May 14, 2011 07:19PM - edited May 14, 2011 07:19PM by Jelson wabi-sabi- of course you had to tell your son. Thank heavens he told you of his concern, just imagine him worrying by himself for weeks. And then of course your other son. I agree that you can hold off telling your daughters until you have a diagnosis. Their being away from home gives you the luxury of sparing them during this period of uncertainty - esp since there is still a good chance that the results will be benign. If it comes to having to tell you daughter in England that you have BC, can you email your daughter in England and tell her that you are having some health issues that you would like to talk with her about via skype (that is where you can see each other?)  and there you will be, looking as lovely and vital as ever - which will make her feel better - I am sure. I told my husband the results of the core biopsy. I didn't have my lumpectomy for several weeks (visitors!) and told my two children, one of whom was living at home and the other nearby - and ages- 20 and 23 at the time - the day before I was to have the lumpectomy - Mother's Day - unfortunately. I told them because they would be around and would notice if I was acting in any way differently.My daughter insisted on coming with her dad and me to the hospital.  I didn't tell anyone else until I actually got the definitive diagnosis after the lumpectomy. My reasoning was - all it would do was upset them with just enough information to drive them and me batshit. I wouldn't have been able to answer their questions, and their comments would not have been reassuring - since they wouldn't have had any factual basis.  Hoping it is benign!! Julie E

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2016 08:58AM Jelson wrote: Faye33 - I am sorry that you have been treated this way and I support your responses- your letter and your resolve to change doctors. I am 7 years out from DCIS and still see my actual RO and MO once a year. My MO - despite the fact that I haven't been on Tamoxifen for 2 years. My annual exam with the MO often gets rescheduled - this time I was given the alternative to see the nurse practitioner which I declined - having the luxury to wait 5 weeks til the doctor would be available. That office has never pulled a switch at the actual visit. I do see the nurse practitioner at my gyno/onc visits. The doctor who performed my hysterectomy left the practice, I was switched to another doctor at my first 3 mo check up where it was made clear to me that I had an excellent prognosis (easier to say with endometrial cancer caught very early than with bc) so being examined every six months by the same nurse practitioner in this instance is totally fine with me. You, HOWEVER, deserve to see the DOCTOR especially after a recurrence of bc AND being in active treatment.
Posts.Title: "Dumped" by my oncologist after 3 years Lindissima LRM216

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2014 09:31PM - edited Jul 7, 2014 09:33PM by Jelson it all sounds like their concern about you having to deal with even the suspicion of breast cancer at your age caused the technicians/staff to act in an emotional and unprofessional manner. The doctor might have picked up on this and the technician's abruptness might have been a result of having been rebuked by the doctor for such innappropriate behavior. In any event, whatever the results are and it sounds like they are benign, it is always a good idea to get copies of your mammograms and ultrasounds in addition to the doctor's report. You can always then get a second opinion. All good wishes for you in your appt with your doctor next week.

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2013 08:02PM Jelson wrote: No Colleen 2, I don't think you are interpreting the lack of response accurately. I think the problem is not many ( of the literally thousands of women on this website who have been diagnosed with BC) have had your experience. Your first responder mentioned scar tissue possibly being the problem and you have had biopsies which may have left scar tissue. That is a reasonable cause for the hardness - hold on to that thought. Hoping your results are benign! Julie E
Posts.Title: Post wire-insertion - Should I be worried? Colleen_2 Colleen_2

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2015 11:53AM Jelson wrote: your doctor should be advocating for you with the insurance co to get your mri bill paid since she/he ordered the test. Perhaps informing her of this gene mutation might provide further evidence that the Mri was medically necessary and that future diagnostic tests will be necessary. Why don't you ask what tests she will perform the 3 month/6 month check up. maybe not as expensive as the first round? also, does your insurance have an annual deductible? you might be close to meeting it this year - if you dawdle, you might have to start at $0 again and incur more out of pocket expenses next year. Please take care of yourself. A month after my annual mammo I had an odd feeling in my breast which amazingly enough, my primary felt. he sent me for an ultra sound - enlarged milk duct - gave me the choice of another ultrasound in 3 months or referral to a breast surgeon - I dawdled a few weeks - chose the BS, who looked at the mammos said it was nothing - but suggested another ultrasound in 3 months - at that ultrasound the duct had become blocked by debris - because I already was a patient of that BS, I quickly got a biopsy which was found to be DCIS , grade 3 and I proceeded to have a lumpectomy. My take away from this was it might have gotten picked up in my next year's mammo, but maybe not. I am thankful that it was caught early. If you have something, which I hope you don't, I hope it is caught early too.

Posts.Title: I learned an important lesson with this scare madalaine CindyNY

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2009 09:22PM Jelson wrote: Hi Weezee, this is the first of your posts that I have seen, I reviewed your older ones but I don't know how other posters responded, so pardon me if I go over old ground. In addition to the discussion boards, this site has a wealth of information about protocols for diagnosing and treating breast cancer. For example, I wondered whether your sister had an oncotype test done? I found info about it here: www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/...  The results are an actual number score which gives the doctor and patient a good idea about whether the patient will actually benefit from chemo. Also, there is information on the hormone therapy which will benefit your sister if her cancer is estrogen+. The different types of hormone therapy are explained on this site here: http://www.breastcancer.org/treatment/hormonal/ Although I am post menopause, because I have been diagnosed with Ductal Cancer In Situ, I am taking Tamoxifen which is actually what most of the premenopausal women take. I have been taking it since September and have not felt any ill-effects. Tamoxifen was the first of the anti-estrogen drugs and originally it was recommended for all women who had estrogen + breast cancer. There are now new drugs which are options for women who are post-menopause whether surgically, chemically or just by plain old age! I consider myself fortunate, if I am to have cancer,then I am glad that it is estrogen + because then I can benefit from hormone therapy!!  If you have not already done so, I would also suggest you check out the Older Women's forum which you will find if you scroll down the discussion board.  This is a terrible blow to your sister who has been dealing with so many issues, how lucky she is to have you, now you take care of yourself!  Julie E
Posts.Title: hormone therapy weezee mawhinney

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2009 08:58AM Jelson wrote:  Dear Liz, http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/34/topic/729220 under get together there is a thread looking for people from the albany area, the originator of the thread is Bethie1 perhaps you could pm her, she was last active on the boards at the end of october. I joined www.Hopeinthboat.org a dragon boat team for breast cancer survivors in the Albany area soon after my diagnosis. At least one member is on the board of CRAAB a capital district breast cancer support organization through which you might get connected to others. Here is the their website http://www.craab.org/ If my neighbor hadn't been diagnosed a month before me and hadn't been visiting in Burlington Vt, on the day of a dragon boat festival in which Hope in the Boat competed, I never would have heard about the team or subsequently CRAAB, through a member of the team. My neighbor linked up through a yoga instructor with another woman who had recently been diagnosed . Since I assume you are looking to share experiences with survivors at a similar stage to yours, I wouldn't presume to suggest our getting together for lunch, but if you are interested, I am available and love to lunch! Julie E I

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2016 11:41AM Jelson wrote: my history was a lump which on ultrasound turned out to be a dilated duct which several months later upon follow-up ultrasound appeared clogged with cells at which time a biopsy was performed and revealed DCIS. I think what is positive about your experience is that you have seen no change over time. from my uneducated perspective - the issue is what is causing the duct to dilate? benign debris or rapidly growing dcis cells - which in my case caused the subsequent ultrasound to appear different. - the needle biopsy is the gold standard - I hope your results are benign - but I think you are doing what you need to do, and if bc is found you are catching it VERY early.

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2009 09:54AM Jelson wrote: Dear Cupid, I can imagine how you feel, like if it wasn't cancer, why did I have to go through all that, pay for and be left damaged? Those are valid questions and you have a right to be sad and confused, but as newday 1976 advises, you can move forward and accomplish what you set your mind to do. Eventhough you didn't have cancer, there are postings on this website that might be of reassurance to you. I checked under Support and Community Connections and there is a discussion board for Young Women -  under age forty and I found a thread discussing childbirth after breast cancer and breast feeding - and I bet there are other threads having to do with breast feeding on that discussion board. When you are pregnant, inform your OB/GYN about your breast surgery and what you were told.  You communicate in English very well. Good luck to you! Julie E
Posts.Title: waited for biospy and got result today (papilloma) cupid104 Eagle713

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2013 04:40PM Jelson wrote: Hi, I too researched it and chose not to ask for it, before being told I wasn't even a candidate due to my tumor having been too close to the skin surface. Here is a lengthy discussion thread from the DCIS board  community.breastcancer.org/for...  for me, 7 weeks of radiation were doable, the facility was close by, went in the morning and kayaked in the afternoon! If you lived far from the radiation facility or had problems with scheduling, the convenience of one week seems to be the primary, if not only reason to choose brachytherapy. Problems with outcomes seem to be related to radiologists not following the protocols regarding to which candidates it should be offered. I would question why the radiologist thinks it is the best alternative - outcome-wise for you in particular. Good luck whatever you decide.

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2014 11:28AM Jelson wrote: I think excisional biopsies used to be more common and that the preference now is for needle/core biopsies instead. However, in your case ( you are special!) it sounds like twol physicians have agreed that the excisional biopsy is better.  As mentioned by Blessings2011, the alternative to an initial excisional biopsy (with general or local anesthesia!!) might end up being multiple little biopsies.  good luck with your procedure and I hope the results are benign.
